div.p: Forgive my remissness: My factotum servant had been ill and I found a lot of work - housemaid’s work - to do on return home.

The MrsDodge who wrote to you is the wife of an amiable American ex architect + present millionaire. Her name is Mabel not Ishmael. She is described as being good natured, generous, harum scarum + chiefly reclining in odalisque yellow satin on more or less priceless rugs in a fine old Florentine villa which, after the manner of persons of taste (I loathe persons of taste, they always destroy everything) the Dodges have reduced to perfect style and total hideousness. For the rest a lady à grands engouements. The small boy . . is a small boy. It is characteristic that they should want a utopian son after having devastated a whole hillside to plant a genuine 17th century garden: you are the authority on utopia and its children, as Berenson is on old masters, hence the letter. I do not think you need bother much about your way of answering. I was taken to Le Mans to see Wilburgh Wright fly (it was like a large grasshopper or rather locust flying whirring round + round a military exercising ground for two hours and the small height gave the idea rather of moving along a wire than of real flying) - and got these postcards for you. Now I see you have written + printed a book on flying (which I shall read) but nevertheless I send these coals to Newcastle; they will amuse your small boys.

Thank you so very much about the English Review. Hüffer preferred an already written spanish ghost story to my unwritten (+ probably never to be written) new one. So I sent it. I want to give this winter to a counter-blast to Pragmatism (in the will-to believe sense) + to my work on literary processes, so I shall have no time for stories. And my stories are always best in my head.
Look: I have read Paley’s paper and your answer; I have read the first paragraph of Paley three times; and, upon my word, I think you are as unfair to him as you accuse him of being to you.

I can see no insinuation of bad faith in his preamble, nothing you have a right to construe into a conspiracy. The remark that he makes i.e. that socialism has now entered onto the converting, conciliatory line, + hence tries to appeal to different kinds of readers, is a most true + harmless one. Why construe it into an accusation of conspiracy? Of course I don’t know what Mallock wrote, nor what this Paley, whom I never heard of before, may have written against you on previous occasions; + I can quite conceive that while ostensibly answering this article, you may be complaining of unfair treatment in other articles. But dear Mr Wells, you must remain fair. That is your great virtue, your distinction, your privilege, what makes us all love you more than almost any other writers. Do not let yourself be goaded into their imitating their attorney’s unfairness or their bad temper. I can’t help writing like this because the beginning of your article (all about the conspiracy) made me down right unhappy. I hate your giving yourself away like that. Forgive my sincerity; I am too gratefully + admiringly attached to you to hide what I think on this occasion. I cannot bear your not always acting up to the perfect kindliness + sincerity which you + all distinguishes you from other writers on such subjects.
div.closer: Give my best + gratefullest love to your wife + believe in my sincere affection, Yrs truly V. Paget
